questions.text: A 45-year-old male presented with difficulty swallowing, weight loss, and a chest X-ray showing associated bronchiectasis. The patient undergoes the contrast study shown below. What is the investigation of choice to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The X-ray shown is a barium swallow (esophagogram), which shows a massively dilated esophagus with a smooth, tapered narrowing at the gastroesophageal junction, creating the classic "bird's beak" sign. This, along with the patient's symptoms of dysphagia and weight loss, is highly suggestive of Achalasia Cardia. The bronchiectasis is likely a secondary finding due to chronic aspiration of retained esophageal contents.

While the esophagogram is an excellent initial test, the gold standard and investigation of choice to confirm this esophageal motility disorder is esophageal manometry. (Option D ruled out)

Esophageal Manometry in Achalasia:

  • Normal LES pressure: 13 mmHg ± 5 (≈ 8-18 mmHg)
  • Achalasia diagnostic value: >25 mmHg (incomplete LES relaxation)
  • Additional manometric findings:
    • Absence of normal peristalsis in the esophageal body
    • Aperistaltic simultaneous contractions
    • Failure of LES to relax completely on swallowing

Explanation of Other Options:

CECT chest (Option B): Useful for ruling out secondary achalasia (pseudoachalasia, e.g., carcinoma at GE junction), but not the primary investigation of choice.

Upper GI Endoscopy (Option C): Upper GI endoscopy is a mandatory part of the workup to rule out a mechanical obstruction or malignancy at the gastroesophageal junction (pseudoachalasia). However, it is often normal or non-diagnostic in primary achalasia.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with right flank pain. A contrast-enhanced CT scan of the abdomen reveals the findings as shown below. Based on the clinical presentation and CT image, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The presence of a solid, enhancing renal mass in an adult on a contrast-enhanced CT (CECT) scan is the classic presentation of Renal Cell Carcinoma (RCC).

Clinical features: Flank pain, hematuria, abdominal mass (classic triad, but uncommon). May also present with systemic features or metastasis.

Imaging:

  • CECT = investigation of choice for diagnosis + staging.
  • MRI = best for venous invasion (renal vein/IVC).
  • Pulmonary metastasis common.

Association: Von Hippel-Lindau syndrome (bilateral RCC, cerebellar hemangioblastoma, retinal hemangioma, pancreatic cysts).

Explanation of other options:

Gallbladder cancer (Option A): This would arise from the gallbladder, which is anatomically distinct from the kidney. The mass is clearly originating from the renal parenchyma.

Retroperitoneal tumor (Option C): While RCC is a retroperitoneal tumor, this option usually implies a tumor arising from the retroperitoneal space outside of the major organs (e.g., a sarcoma). The image clearly shows an intra-renal mass.

Left lobe liver abscess (Option D): This is incorrect as the pathology is in the right kidney, not the left lobe of the liver. Furthermore, an abscess typically appears as a rim-enhancing fluid collection, not a solid enhancing mass.

Key Takeaways:

  • Solid renal mass in adult = RCC (until proven otherwise).
  • CECT is IOC for diagnosis and staging.
  • MRI preferred for evaluation of IVC/renal vein invasion.
  • Renal oncocytoma: Central stellate non-enhancing scar (important differential).
  • Commonest neonatal renal tumor: Congenital mesoblastic nephroma.

questions.text: A newborn is admitted to the NICU in the first 24 hours of birth with severe dyspnea/respiratory distress. A chest x-ray is done, which is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical presentation of severe, immediate-onset respiratory distress in a newborn combined with the classic X-ray findings is diagnostic for a Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia (CDH). The X-ray shows multiple cystic, air-filled structures (loops of bowel) within the left chest cavity, a C/L shift of the mediastinum, and a scaphoid abdomen due to the displacement of abdominal contents into the chest.

Explanation of Other Options:

Congenital Pulmonary Airway Malformation (CPAM) (Option B): This would appear as a cystic or solid mass within a lung lobe, not as clearly defined bowel loops filling the entire hemithorax. The abdominal gas pattern would be normal.

Loculated pneumothorax (Option C): Presents as a localized hyperlucent area without lung markings, not bowel gas shadows.

Congenital lobar emphysema (Option D): This is the massive hyperinflation of a single lung lobe (commonly the left upper lobe). The X-ray would show a hyper-expanded, hyperlucent lobe (yellow arrow) compressing the surrounding lung and shifting the mediastinum (white arrow), but no bowel loops would be seen in the chest.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with a right-sided neck swelling, which is pulsatile in nature and is compressible, refilling on removal of pressure. A CT-angiogram was performed and is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The combination of clinical findings (a pulsatile, compressible neck mass) and the pathognomonic imaging feature is diagnostic of a carotid body tumor. This is a type of paraganglioma, a rare and typically benign neuroendocrine tumor arising from the chemoreceptor cells of the carotid body.

Carotid body tumour:

It arises from the carotid body at the bifurcation of the common carotid artery.

  • Clinical features: Presents as a pulsatile, compressible neck swelling, often with bruit/thrill. The tumor can be moved side to side but not up and down, due to its location within the carotid sheath (Fontaine's sign)
  • Common Associations:
    • Seen in familial paraganglioma syndromes (SDH gene mutations).
    • Syndromic association: Can occur in MEN-2, Von Hippel-Lindau disease, NF type 1.
    • High altitude: D/t chronic hypoxia stimulating the carotid body.
  • CT-angiogram: Shows the classic "lyre sign" - splaying of the internal and external carotid arteries by an enhancing mass.
  • MRI: Demonstrates the "salt and pepper appearance" (salt = hyperintense foci from slow flow/hemorrhage; pepper = flow voids from high vascularity).
  • Management: Surgical excision (with or without preoperative embolization). Biopsy is contraindicated due to high risk of bleeding.

Explanation of Other Options:

Carotid aneurysm (Option B): This would appear as a saccular or fusiform dilation of the carotid artery itself on angiography, not as a distinct solid tumor splaying the bifurcation.

AV fistula (Option C): Usually post-traumatic or iatrogenic; causes a continuous bruit/thrill with imaging showing a direct arterial-venous communication. On angiography, it would be characterized by very early and dense filling of veins during the arterial phase, not a well-defined tumor mass.

Hemangioma (Option D): Benign vascular tumor, usually cutaneous/subcutaneous, more common in children, not classically located at the carotid bifurcation.

questions.text: Identify the correct features of the investigation shown in the given image.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Intravenous Urography (IVU), also called Intravenous Pyelography (IVP), is a non-invasive, contrast-based imaging technique of the renal parenchyma, pelvicalyceal system, ureters, and bladder.

  • Mechanism: Intravenous iodinated contrast is injected, filtered by kidneys, and sequential X-rays are taken to visualize both anatomical and functional information (excretion pattern, obstruction).
  • Uses:
    • Detect ureteropelvic junction obstruction
    • Demonstrate renal/ureteric calculi
    • Evaluate hydronephrosis, congenital anomalies
    • Evaluation of obstructive uropathy
  • Limitations: Replaced in most centres by CT urography; risk of contrast nephropathy and allergy.

Explanation of Other Options:

Invasive and therapeutic for bladder calculi (Option A): Cystoscopy with lithotripsy is therapeutic. IVU is diagnostic, not therapeutic.

Gold standard for bladder cancer (Option C): Cystoscopy with biopsy is the gold standard for bladder cancer. An IVU may show a filling defect, but it is not the primary or definitive test.

Requires percutaneous access to the renal system (Option D): This statement describes a different procedure called an Percutaneous Nephrostography / Antegrade Pyelography. An IVU involves the injection of contrast into a peripheral vein

questions.solution:

Explanation of Other Options:

Glioma (Option A): Typically intra-axial, arising from brain parenchyma, often infiltrative and heterogeneously enhancing depending on grade; lacks extra-axial signs and a dural tail.

Ependymoma (Option B): Arises from ependymal cells lining the ventricular system (often fourth ventricle in children) and is therefore typically intraventricular or periventricular. They commonly show heterogeneous enhancement, calcifications, or cystic change and would not present as a peripheral dural-based mass.

Pilocytic astrocytoma (Option D): Usually a pediatric tumor, often cystic with a mural nodule (classically cerebellar), well-circumscribed, and WHO grade I. Less likely to present as a dural-based, homogeneously enhancing lesion in an adult.

questions.text: An 8-year-old presents to the orthopedics OPD with complaints of a painless limp for the past 1 week. An X-ray is done and is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This child's age, presentation of painless limp, and X-ray changes are classic for Perthes disease.

Perthes disease (Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease) is an idiopathic avascular necrosis of the femoral head seen commonly in boys aged 4-10 years.

  • Clinical feature: Painless limp (most common presentation) ± mild hip/knee pain.
  • X-ray findings: Fragmentation, flattening, and sclerosis of femoral head with loss of normal spherical contour.
  • Pathology: Interruption of blood supply → avascular necrosis → collapse and regeneration of femoral head.
  • Complication: Hip deformity and osteoarthritis if untreated.

Explanation of Other Options:

Developmental Dysplasia of the Hip (DDH) (Option A): This condition typically presents in infancy with hip instability. Clinical signs include limited abduction, leg length discrepancy, positive Barlow/Ortolani tests, not painless limp in an older child. The X-ray findings would be a shallow acetabulum and a superolaterally displaced femoral head, not a fragmented one.

Slipped Capital Femoral Epiphysis (SCFE) (Option B): It typically affects obese adolescents (10-16 years) and presents with a painful limp. The characteristic X-ray finding is a posteroinferior slip of the femoral epiphysis (described as an "ice cream scoop falling off a cone"), not fragmentation. A key diagnostic sign on an AP X-ray is a positive Trethowan's sign, where Klein's line (drawn along the superior femoral neck) fails to intersect the slipped femoral head.

Tuberculosis Hip (Option D): Presents with painful limp, night cries, fever, weight loss. X-ray shows narrowing of joint space, periarticular osteopenia, and erosions (Phemister’s triad), not fragmentation of femoral head.
